Issues.Title: misleading documentation on :host and :host-context directives
Issues.Body:
# üìö Docs or angular.io bug report

### Description

Docs state that I can use special selectors to go "above" the component into the parent. But they're totally wrong. Component styles won't "escape" the prison of the component and there's no way to target host element (other than ng-deep).  See stackblitz below.

Let's go through the doc problems:

> Use the :host pseudo-class selector to target styles in the element that hosts the component (as opposed to targeting elements inside the component's template).

* `:host(.parabove) { color: magenta;}`  never gets applied to `div.parabove`. 
* `:host {  color: pink; } ` gets applied to `<child` tag itself, which means `:host === child tag space`. 

-> This should be rewritten as "You will never be able to jump out of component's css prison. `:host` targets the element itself, it will never go "beyond" the component.

> :host-context  Sometimes it's useful to apply styles based on some condition outside of a component's view

Never ever you will escape the component prison. This should be clearly stated with no double meaning.  _outside of component's view_ is a double-meaning wording, it implies that that's possible by some tiny luck, even if it refers to the CONDITION and not to the CSS style application itself. Wording should be corrected. Double-emphasize the "condition".

> yle to all <h2> elements _inside_ the compon

I like how you highlighted the "inside" word. You had probably gotten hell lot of tickets and questions related to that. This should really be emphasized even more. Don't use words that might saw doubt or express possibility, instead state clearly and strongly that it's impossible to get out of element's scope from within the component CSS.

It's also funny how the wording is correct around these :host selector sections --
Above the :host you find paragraph that has a red plank with "_The styles specified in @Component metadata apply only within the template of that component._", the paragraph that comes after the :host section mentions ::ng-deep with "_styles normally apply only to the HTML in the component's own template_". Thus, everything is right in those paragraphs, it's just this :host and :host-context para is confusing.
Remember, there are lots of ESL users whose brains might not "click in" on right words or in right moments. Find a native English speaker and ask him to proof-read and eliminate the confusion. Thanks.

## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction

https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-ivy-ceftph?file=src%2Fapp%2Fchild.component.scss

No

When binding to radio inputs, using `[name]="myNameVariable"` does not apply the attr.name value, meaning the tab order does not work. The two solutions to this are to use both `[name]` and `[attr.name]` together, or to just use ~~name="{{myNameVariable}}"~~ (just found out while writing this that only `name="nonVariableString"` will set both the attr.name and ng-reflect, using `{{}}` interpolation doesn't work making this extra annoying) which sets both values. This is strange behaviour that isn't immediately obvious. Ideally `[name]` should also set attr.name as well as the ng-reflect.

I will be honest I am not sure what is happening behind the scenes with this component so I'm not even sure if this is possible or desired but its confusing when standard attribute names are hijacked for angular specific implementation and it prevents the native html from working.

Issues.Title: build: ensure script that build the Zone.js package can be run from any directory
Issues.Body:
The scripts that build the Angular and Zone.js NPM packages rely on absolute paths in order to work correctly regardless of what the current working directory is when the scripts are invoked. However, the `npm pack` command executed in the `zone-js-builder.js` script outputs the generated `.tgz` archive in the current working directory. This causes the script to fail when invoked for any working directory other than the project root directory.

This commit fixes this by ensuring the `npm pack` command is run with the project root directory as the working directory. This allows the build scripts to run correctly regardless of the working directory they are invoked from.

When there is a primary outlet present in the outlets map and the object is also prefixed

the others. This change ensures that all outlets are respected at the
segment level when prefixed with other commands.

# üêû Bug report

### Command (mark with an `x`)
<!-- Can you pin-point the command or commands that are effected by this bug? -->
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏èedit: -->

- [ ] new

- [ ] config
- [ ] help
- [ ] version
- [ ] doc


### Is this a regression?
Maybe.


### Description
`@charset "UTF-8";` not lifted to the top of the css file when `@import url()` used. Instead, all the `@import url()`s are listed first.

As far as how this affects the user, it seems like chrome is still able to figure things out, most of the time.  One way to force it to mess up due to this is to load the app, open dev tools, and then reload the app. That is probably a separate chrome bug.


## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction
Here is a repo that exhibits the problem. Note the second commit that changes 2 files to make this happen:
https://github.com/SLKnutson/angular-bug
Run `ng build --configuration="production"` and then look at the dist/styles.css file.
Charset needs to be the first line in the file, but it is not.


## üåç Your Environment
Found in mac and linux, haven't tried Windows

**Anything else relevant?**
If node-sass is used, this problem doesn't occur because node-sass doesn't change the '\f103' into a unicode character, and so no `@charset "UTF-8";` is needed.

When optimization=true in angular.json, the error is fixed.

I've done a little bit of digging, the css looks good coming out of the actual sass compiler, but gets messed up somewhere after that.

Thanks!

`$localize`, which allows messages in application code to have the same
id as identical messages in templates.

for i18n messages, this commit updates newly generated projects to turn
off the legacy ids.

In the future the default will be flipped and this can be removed.
Eventually the legacy message id support will be removed altogether,
probably in sync with removal of ViewEngine.

`@ngtools/webpack` (`AngularCompilerPlugin`)

Issues.Title: bug(overlay): Push calculation is wrong with FlexibleConnectedPositionStrategy
Issues.Body:
## Bug description

Push calculation is wrong [in this line](https://github.com/angular/components/blob/0b2d150339fb6e5736ea199bc62785ec1d2e8928/src/cdk/overlay/position/flexible-connected-position-strategy.ts#L614). Maybe in the next lines also, but I did not check it yet.

I tried to add an element, that perfectly fits, but I could not. I realized that the double of the original margin is used on the right side. I used LTR.

### Input

Take a document, that has 400px width. The margin is 20px on the viewport of the overlay. I tried to add one overlay at (300, 20) with size of (80,40). I will use this in the stackblitz and in the calculations.

#### Reproduction

https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-ardamx

![overlay](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6360699/97225389-df307d00-17d2-11eb-8399-e5a339d20aca.gif)

As you see the overlay is positioned well at the begining. 100px is the container. 80px is the overlay. 10-80-10 is well positioned.

If the body element is 420px width, the position is right. 0-80-20.

If the body is shrinked more to 400px, the position will not be 0-80-20, however it could fit.

#### Expected Behavior

pushX to be 0 in this case. The element should fit without pushing it. The margin should be 20px on the right, too.

#### Actual Behavior

start.x is 300, the width is 80 as these are given. The viewport width is 360px (=400px-2*20px).

pushX will be -20 as overflowRight is 20. This is calculated by 300+80-360=20.

This is wrong. The element can fit without pushing it. The margin is now the double of the originally given, which is 40px in this case.

#### Environment

- Angular: 10.1.3
- CDK/Material: 10.2.5
- Browser(s): Chrome (Could be any)
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): macOS (Could be any)
